ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
I gained a comprehensive education in writing for television, from defining the constituent components of a TV franchise to experiencing the inherently collaborative nature of the television writing process.  We discussed scene writing, sketching characters, writing loglines, making plans, playing into/against tropes, escalation, complication, and plot. 
In short, Professor Green taught an excellent class in writing for the small screen while simultaneously showing us what it looks like to lead and participate in a writer's room.

This course helped me feel comfortable writing a television drama -- such a valuable skill !! The first half of the semester was spent reading and discussing well-known scripts, and the second half was spent reading and discussing our own. I think these discussions were the most insightful and helpful that I've experienced at Yale thus far.
How to write and give feedback on TV scripts for drama.
How to write and analyze TV Drama, with more advanced techniques than "Writing the TV Drama"

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Well-structured and effective in turning our class into a community. The collaborative nature of the course (I.e. those end-of-class discussions and class-wide workshops) allowed us to get to know each other and even lead to us spending time as a class outside of the classroom. The balance of talking about television to writing to actually writing television was pitch-perfect.

This was truly a phenomenal course. Professor Green was incredibly helpful in guiding us as much as we needed through the script-writing process while also giving us lots of time and space to work on our craft independently. In-class discussions were amazing. If you're looking for a course that will help you write a script step-by-step, you won't find that here -- it's much more free than that -- which I think was a strength. Professor Green encouraged all students to set up one-on-one meetings with him to talk about our writing processes in detail.

This was an excellent course and its strength is definitely in the quality and enthusiasm of the class. The class became a great community, created by frequent pitching and sharing of ideas early on in the course.

Strengths: You get to read many scripts and get a sense of how to write a TV pilot, you get plenty of feedback on your writing, class turns into a "writer's room" where students assess each other's work in a collaborative way, interesting guest speakers. Prof Green is passionate/insightful and an absolute win for Yale.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I'd recommend this class and any class taught by Professor Green, who is truly one of the best advisors and professors in all of Yale. Whether you are interested in TV writing or rare bird sighting, learning about the core constituents of storytelling with Professor Green will make you a better communicator, writer, and conversationalist about the things you love. Overall, this a 10/10 course taught by a 10/10 professor.
Yes, if you are interested in writing or film and media, this class is an excellent way to focus on the skills of these subjects.
YES! I am so much more confident in my writing and my ability to structure a script. I loved this course and cannot recommend it highly enough.

I would definitely recommend this course! You need to be interested and willing to read at least three full TV and movie scripts each week. The workshop is an invaluable place to receive serious feedback from both the professor and other students on your work.
Yes -- would highly recommend this course to aspiring Film/TV people! One of my favorite courses at Yale.

extras.title: ENGL 461 01 - The Art and Craft of TV Drama
